body: 'THE CHARLIE BROWN CHRISTMAS' Linus's grungy blanket, Charlie Brown's hairs, Lucy's attitude: the whole Peanuts gang will become three-dimensional this weekend when the young theater company Pig Brooch stages a verbatim re-enactment of ''A Charlie Brown Christmas,'' the perennial, and perennially beloved, TV special. ''Metaphorically, everyone has
title: Spare Times

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites MERCHANT'S HOUSE MUSEUM, 29 East Fourth Street, East Village. Friday at 7 p.m., ''To All, Wassail,'' a performance by the Bond Street Euterpean Singing Society; $15, free for members. Through Jan. 12, ''Christmas Trees of Old New York -- Roots of Tradition,'' an exhibition on the history of holiday decorations. (212)
title: Spare Times

body: Always crowded and often perilous, the twisting road that brought the Sucuzhañay family from Ecuador to New York City has transformed the city, first neighborhoods in Queens and more recently parts of Brooklyn where surging numbers of newcomers have made Ecuadoreans one of New York's largest Hispanic communities. The father came first. In the
title: Killing Haunts Ecuadoreans' Rise in New York

body: The church custodian saw him first: a man alone in a parking lot, swinging a folding chair like an ax, bringing it down toward the windshield of a parked van and stopping, an inch from the glass. Then backing up and dancing around with the chair, a strange ballet. Then swinging again, over and over. The custodian yelled for the man to stop, and
title: A Flash of Menace, and a Death by Police Bullet

body: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will seek to increase fare and toll revenues by 23 percent next year to plug a yawning budget gap, according to a person briefed on the plan. But the increase will not be enough on its own. Faced with its worst financial problems in more than two decades, the authority has also drafted proposals for deep
title: M.T.A. Said to Plan 23% Increase in Fare and Toll Revenue

body: Four minutes into their first home game on Saturday night, the Brooklyn Aces of the Eastern Professional Hockey League began defending their frozen turf on Flatbush Avenue. Jerry Cardinale, one of Brooklyn's own, squared off at center ice with Teague Willits-Kelley of the Jersey Rockhoppers. As both players tossed their helmets and gloves to the
title: Watch Out for That Stick, Er, Fist: Professional Ice Hockey Bursts Into Brooklyn

body: City officials said on Wednesday that they would spend $11.3 billion to create 42 schools enrolling 25,000 children over the next five years, a far less ambitious agenda for building and renovation than the capital plan presented five years ago. The scaled-down blueprint, quietly released hours after Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced the city's
title: With Budget Shrinking, Schools Will Get Fewer New Buildings

body: FOR years, residents of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, have complained about a dearth of fresh produce in the neighborhood, and the problem seemed to only worsen in June with the closing of a Key Food on Third Avenue and 94th Street. So when word spread that a farmers' market would open on Oct. 4 in the parking lot of the shuttered Key Food, much rejoicing
title: BAY RIDGE; A Greenmarket, With a Clock Ticking

body: It seemed that the four young men from Brooklyn had always been together. As children, they rode Big Wheels and then bicycles on the streets of Dyker Heights, their friends said. By the time they finished high school, they were working the cash registers and eating their meals in the popular Italian restaurants and markets run by their families.
title: 4 Lifetime Pals Go Fishing, And Only One Comes Home

author: Jan Stuart is the author of ''The Nashville Chronicles: The Making of Robert Altman's Masterpiece.''
body: TWO MARRIAGES Novellas By Phillip Lopate 264 pp. Other Press. $24.95 Denial is alive and well and churning in Dyker Heights, the Brooklyn neighborhood that colors the giddy curtain raiser of ''Two Marriages,'' Phillip Lopate's double bill of novellas. The thrillingly clueless narrator of ''The Stoic's Marriage'' is Gordon, a pudgy, pushing-50 idler
title: Too Late the Misanthrope

body: VICTORIA HOFMO, a native of Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, who has long blond hair and sky blue eyes, grew up only vaguely aware of her Scandinavian background. At Christmas, her family used to eat a Norwegian rice porridge called risgrot; the person who found the almond hidden inside got a special gift. Ms. Hofmo's grandmother, who died when she was 13,
title: THE VOICE; When Brooklyn Was Norway

body: THE sand at the southern tip of New York, sad to say, is filthy. That much is clear even from a dozen feet above sea level, on the covered deck that overlooks the beach in Tottenville, the town at the bottom of Staten Island. Walk down to the beach and the picture is no prettier: the remains of a case of Coors Light, some takeout containers, and a
title: DISPATCHES; The Old Beer Cans and the Sea

body: ABOUT three years ago, Christian Zaino, an undergraduate at New York University, found that the history of Dyker Heights, his southwest Brooklyn neighborhood near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, had not yet been fully documented. So he made it the topic of his senior thesis, poring over archived stories from the daily Brooklyn Eagle and joining up
title: LIVING IN | DYKER HEIGHTS, BROOKLYN; Short on Subway Stops, Long on Christmas Lights

body: Dyker Heights, in southwestern Brooklyn, is far from the subway but offers visitors an eyeful of ornate architecture and a rich Italian-American ambience.
title: Living in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn

body: Competition and rivalry are common in politics, just as they are within families. But it is highly uncommon for a family rivalry to boil over into politics, and that is just what has occurred in the race for the Congressional seat that is being vacated by Representative Vito J. Fossella of Staten Island. The Republican candidate is Francis H.
title: G.O.P. Candidate for Congress Faces Challenge From His Son

body: Republican leaders in Staten Island on Thursday night endorsed Francis H. Powers, a retired Wall Street executive, as their candidate for the Congressional seat being vacated by Representative Vito J. Fossella. Mr. Powers, known within the party primarily for his fund-raising efforts for several Staten Island candidates, has not run for public
title: Republicans Back Ex-Wall Street Executive to Run for Fossella's Seat

body: The Security of a Lock, the Invincibility of Youth To the Editor: The article about the old Fox police lock (''When the Deadbolt Was Not Enough,'' April 27) brought back memories of my first apartment. Having just graduated from City College in 1972, I lined up a small shoe box: Apartment 3C at 18 West 87th Street, near Central Park West. One day
title: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR; Of Locks, Beauty and Driveways

author: More Dispatches: nytimes.com/cityroom
body: EVEN on a quiet evening last week, without a construction worker in sight, there were signs of the neighborhood strife that has taken over a stretch of 70th Street in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn. A blue tarpaulin was draped over an unfinished porch renovation, and in front of that house, behind barriers and yellow tape, was a smooth, pale new stretch
title: DISPATCHES; Driveway, He Said

body: They found the remains of Firefighter Jimmy Riches in the rubble of the World Trade Center on March 25, 2002. A brother, Tom Riches, then just 17, walked down into the pit, and he and his father and his other two brothers carried Jimmy out on a stretcher. On Sunday morning, six years later, Tom Riches walked once again into the hole. There, about
title: In the Pit, With the Pope and Memories of a Brother

body: The candy canes were the first to go. Just before 10 on Tuesday morning, a beat-up white van pulled up to Michael Mazza's house in Dyker Heights, Brooklyn. A worker emerged from the van, climbed the stone stairs to Mr. Mazza's well-trod lawn and began shouldering out candy canes one by one. In the unforgiving glare of a balmy January day, they
title: DYKER HEIGHTS JOURNAL; Demolition Crews Go to Work on a Winter Wonderland
